packages.name: Julia
packages.copyrightText: Copyright (c) 2009-2021: Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral B. Shah, and other contributors: https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/contributors
packages.summary: Julia is a high-level, high-performance dynamic language for technical computing.
packages.comment: In addition to the source code described by this package, Julia pulls in code from many other respositories, which are also described in this document. See relationships for details.

packages.name: Pkg.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/Pkg.version
packages.copyrightText: Copyright (c) 2017-2021: Stefan Karpinski, Kristoffer Carlsson, Fredrik Ekre, David Varela, Ian Butterworth, and contributors: https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/graphs/contributors
packages.summary: Julia's package manager, shipped with Julia v1.0 and above

packages.name: Statistics.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/Statistics.version
packages.copyrightText: Copyright (c) 2012-2016: Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral B. Shah, Dahua Lin, Simon Byrne, Andreas Noack, Douglas Bates, John Myles White, Simon Kornblith, and other contributors.
packages.summary: Development repository for the Statistics standard library (stdlib) that ships with Julia.

packages.name: libCURL.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/libCURL.version

packages.name: Downloads.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/Downloads.version
packages.summary: The Downloads package provides a single function, download, which provides cross-platform, multi-protocol, in-process download functionality implemented with libcurl.

packages.name: ArgTools.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/ArgTools.version
packages.summary: ArgTools provides tools for creating consistent, flexible APIs that work with various kinds of function arguments.

packages.name: Tar.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/Tar.version
packages.summary: The Tar package can list, extract and create POSIX TAR archives (tarballs) as specified in POSIX 1003.1-2001.

packages.name: NetworkOptions.jl
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file stdlib/NetworkOptions.version
packages.summary: The NetworkOptions package acts as a mediator between ways of configuring network transport mechanisms (SSL/TLS, SSH, proxies, etc.) and Julia packages that provide access to transport mechanisms.

packages.name: OpenBLAS
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file deps/openblas.version
packages.summary: OpenBLAS is an optimized BLAS library based on GotoBLAS2 1.13 BSD version.

packages.name: libuv
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file deps/libuv.version
packages.summary: libuv is a multi-platform support library with a focus on asynchronous I/O. It was primarily developed for use by Node.js, but it's also used by Luvit, Julia, pyuv, and others.
packages.comment: The Julia project has forked libuv and maintains their own repository of the code

packages.name: zlib
packages.sourceInfo: The git hash of the version in use can be found in the file deps/zlib.version
packages.copyrightText: Copyright (C) 1995-2017 Jean-loup Gailly and Mark Adler
packages.summary: A massively spiffy yet delicately unobtrusive compression library.

packages.name: patchelf
packages.sourceInfo: The version in use can be found in the file deps/Versions.make
packages.summary: A small utility to modify the dynamic linker and RPATH of ELF executables.
packages.comment: PATCHELF is not part of the Julia binary. It is a tool used as part of building the binary, a bit like a compiler. Julia chooses to build the tool from source during the build process as a convienence.
